headline: Heard on the Street: Credit Fears Are Spreading to Consumer Lending
summary: The market’s fears about loans aren’t limited to what’s happening with private credit.  Student-lender SLM Corp., online lenders LendingClub and Upstart, buy now-pay later provider Affirm and card giants American Express, Capital One Financial and Synchrony Financial were all down at least 6% on Friday.  Also on Thursday, VantageScore reported that its CreditGauge tracker was seeing sharp increases in early-stage credit delinquencies across all tiers of borrowers in January, with the sharpest increase actually coming among well-heeled “superprime” consumers.

headline: The Dow’s ‘Citrini Selloff’ Is Back. Blame Block.
summary: Block’s mass layoffs reignited Wall Street’s paranoia about artificial intelligence advancements. The Dow fell 588 points, or 1.2%. The S&P 500 was down 0.6%. The Nasdaq Composite was down 0.8%. Among the hardest hit stocks in the Dow were American Express, Goldman Sachs Group, Salesforce, and JPMorgan Chase.

headline: American Express Has Slumped: Is It a Bargain or a Red Flag?
summary: American Express (NYSE: AXP) has slipped 15% year-to-date as of February 27, pulling back from a 52-week high of $387.49 to around $315, while the broader market is essentially flat year-to-date. For long-term holders, the question is whether this is a dip worth buying or an early signal of something structural. The Bear Case: Real ... American Express Has Slumped: Is It a Bargain or a Red Flag?

headline: Dow Is on Pace for Its Worst Week of the Year
summary: The Dow is having its worst week of the year.  The blue-chip index is down 725 points, or 1.5% this week, which would be its largest decline on a percent and point basis since the week of Nov. 21, 2025, according to Dow Jones Market Data.  Friday’s slide was led by American Express, Goldman Sachs, Salesforce, JPMorgan Chase.
